title: FirstFT: Today's top stories
text:
Washington and Beijing are hammering out the details of the first high-level meeting between the rival powers since President Joe Biden took office, according to four people familiar with the talks.

The negotiations could lead to a meeting of Antony Blinken, secretary of state, and Jake Sullivan, national security adviser, with their Chinese counterparts — possibly in Alaska.

The discussions come as Biden is poised to hold the first ever quadrilateral US summit with the leaders of Japan, India and Australia, as they step up co-operation in an effort to counter China's influence in the Indo-Pacific. The US is already talking to the three countries to develop a plan to distribute Covid-19 vaccines to countries in Asia.

There are also concerns the US military is losing its edge in the region. On Tuesday Admiral Philip Davidson, America's top commander in the Indo-Pacific, warned that the military balance in the region had “become more unfavourable” to the US. (FT)

Coronavirus digest

  • Mexico's government has doubled its order for a vaccine made by China's Sinopharm. China's biggest vaccine developer is betting that the urgent need to inoculate billions of people across the world will finally allow it to establish its credentials as a global supplier.

  • Russia is seeking to manufacture its Sputnik V vaccine in Italy to meet a surge in overseas contracts. Vaccine diplomacy has presented a dilemma for foreign embassies in Moscow that are relying on airlifts of domestically approved jabs, writes Henry Foy.

  • Italy has identified reform and infrastructure investments to support women as priorities when it spends more than €200bn of EU recovery funds.

  • Almost a fifth more men than women have died from coronavirus in the UK, according to a new report that also suggests women's wellbeing and working lives are being hit harder by the pandemic than men.

  • Covid-19 has been blamed for sharp declines in the number of babies being born nine months or more after lockdowns in France, Italy and Spain. (FT)

The number of worldwide vaccinations has hit more than 310m doses, the Financial Times' tracker showed. Follow our Covid-19 live blog for the latest updates.

In the news

Nasdaq's best day since November The Nasdaq Composite gained 3.7 per cent on Tuesday, a day after the technology index slumped into correction territory. Asia-Pacific shares rose and global sentiment brightened in the wake of the rebound on Wall Street, which was led by Big Tech stocks including Tesla, Apple and Amazon. (FT)

Apollo's Greensill bid crumbles Apollo Global Management's plan to buy parts of stricken finance company Greensill Capital out of administration is on the verge of collapse, according to people familiar with the matter.

  • Japanese insurer Tokio Marine has said the insurance policies at the heart of the Greensill Capital collapse may not have been valid, as investors pressed the company to detail its exposure to the lender.

GE to sell aircraft leasing business to AerCap The deal, valued at $30bn, brings together the world's two biggest aircraft-leasing businesses and marks a further step in the dismantling of the US industrial group's financial arm. (FT)

Retail investor apathy threatens Spac deals A growing number of acquisitions by blank cheque companies risk being derailed as retail investors fail to show up in sufficient numbers for critical shareholder votes, forcing backers of the deals to embrace unorthodox social-media strategies to turn out votes. (FT)

Banks adopt new debt terms US banks have begun inserting legal terms in debt documents to protect themselves against accidental fund transfers after Citigroup lost a legal battle to recoup $500m of the $900m it had wired to creditors of cosmetic group Revlon last year. (FT)

Oprah shows broadcast TV can still make a splash Oprah Winfrey's dramatic interview with Meghan Markle and Prince Harry attracted an average of 17.1m viewers in the US, the largest primetime audience for any entertainment special in more than a year. “Oprah, the royals, CBS, it all felt very vintage,” said one media executive. (FT)

  • The rift between Britain's royal family and two of its most charismatic and crowd-pleasing members represents a vast missed opportunity to modernise the institution, writes the FT's editorial board.

Biden considers prominent tech critic for top government job The Biden administration is vetting Lina Khan, a prominent critic of large technology companies, for a senior government role, two people with knowledge of the vetting process told the Financial Times. (FT)

  • Venture capitalists are investing at the fastest pace in more than a decade, intensifying competition for stakes in young Silicon Valley tech companies and increasing concerns about inflated valuations. (FT)

Chevron sets target of ‘higher returns, lower carbon' Chevron said in an investor presentation on Tuesday that it would power more of its operations with renewables, slash methane emissions from its shale operations and invest more than $1bn to capture and store carbon from its plants as part of an effort to clean up its oil and gas business. (FT)

Jury selection begins for officer charged in Floyd killing Jury selection began on Tuesday in the trial of Derek Chauvin, the police officer accused of killing Minneapolis resident George Floyd, whose death set off sweeping protests against racial injustice in the US and around the world. (FT)

The day ahead

US stimulus vote Lawmakers in the House are expected to pass the Biden administration's $1.9tn Covid-19 relief bill over Republican opposition on Wednesday, setting the president up to sign the bill into law later this week. (FT)

IPOs The South Korean ecommerce company Coupang expects its shares to soar past the $50bn valuation when it lists in New York. Shares in the games platform Roblox also begin trading today. (FT)

Earnings Enterprise software company Oracle reports earnings today. The world's largest cinema operator AMC Entertainment and Bumble, the online dating business which recently listed on the Nasdaq exchange, also report results. (FT)

Data The US Bureau of Labor Statistics will release the consumer price index for February 2021. There has been a lot of speculation recently that inflation is about to make a comeback. (FT)

What else we're reading

Car groups complicate EU's hydrogen drive Europe's two biggest industrial and economic powers are laying billions on the table in an attempt to take on China in developing a “green” hydrogen sector to replace fossil fuels — but the continent's top motor groups are wary of going along for the ride. (FT)

The case for investing in bitcoin Scepticism over cryptocurrencies has roots in the framework of money as a medium of exchange, unit of account and store of value. But there are good reasons for business leaders to invest in them as an opportunity to solve a number of problems — particularly in emerging economies, writes economist Dambisa Moyo. (FT)

Humanity is a cuckoo in the planetary nest We have had dramatic success in increasing our wealth and numbers, writes Martin Wolf. But as extinction rates increase, there is no doubt our activities are reshaping life on earth. If we wish to reverse these threats, what must we do and give up? (FT)

How Ron Kim became Andrew Cuomo's nemesis As a shamefaced Andrew Cuomo was scraping the depths of his political career, publicly apologising for his mistreatment of women, Ron Kim was scaling new heights. The New York state assembly member from Queens has campaigned for nursing home reforms in the face of opposition from the three-term governor. (FT)

Europe's push to police ESG investing As environmental, social and governance issues become part of the investment mainstream, sustainable investing is reaching a critical juncture: without some way to police the concept, it risks being reduced to a marketing exercise with only modest substance. New EU rules against “greenwashing” could prevent that. (FT)

Video of the day

Vaccine economics The FT asks whether the pandemic will fundamentally change the vaccine market, featuring global experts including Bill Gates, the chief executives of Moderna and Gavi and the lead scientist behind the Oxford/AstraZeneca vaccine. (FT)
